In a monoid with zero and a topology, an element is topologically nilpotent if its powers converge to zero.

In a ring with a linear topology, sum and product of (commuting) topologically nilpotent elements are topologically nilpotent.

Le 23 janvier 2025 12:04:44 GMT+01:00, Anatole Dedecker ***@***.***> a écrit :
>@ADedecker commented on this pull request.
>
>
>
>> +theorem pow_mem_of_pow_mem {m n : ℕ} (ha : a ^ m ∈ I) (h : m ≤ n) : a ^ n ∈ I := by
>+  rw [← Nat.add_sub_of_le h, pow_add]
>+  exact I.mul_mem_right _ _ ha
>+
>+theorem add_pow_mem_of_pow_mem_of_le {m n k : ℕ}
>+    (ha : a ^ m ∈ I) (hb : b ^ n ∈ I) (hk : m + n ≤ k + 1) (h : Commute a b) :
>+    (a + b) ^ k ∈ I := by
>+  rw [h.add_pow]
>+  apply I.finsetSum_mem
>+  intro c _
>+  apply mul_mem_right
>+  by_cases h : m ≤ c
>+  · exact I.mul_mem_right _ _ (I.pow_mem_of_pow_mem ha h)
>+  · refine I.mul_mem_left _ _ (I.pow_mem_of_pow_mem hb ?_)
>+    omega
>+
>+theorem add_pow_add_pred_mem_of_pow_mem {m n : ℕ}
>+    (ha : a ^ m ∈ I) (hb : b ^ n ∈ I) (h : Commute a b) :
>+    (a + b) ^ (m + n - 1) ∈ I :=
>+  I.add_pow_mem_of_pow_mem_of_le ha hb (by rw [← Nat.sub_le_iff_le_add]) h
>
>That shouldn't require that much generalizing, right? To be clear I think that would fit in this PR.
>
>-- 
>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
>https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20971#discussion_r1926793541
>You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
>
>Message ID: ***@***.***>

It sounds to me that all of these should be true for left ideals as well thanks to the commutation hypotheses, right? I recognize it's a bit unsatisfying to be able to state them for left ideals but not right ideals, but I think it would still be better not to restrict to two-sided ideals.

On the other hand, having this for ideals requires to generalize (it is often trivial) lemmas from `CommSemiring` to `Semiring` in much earlier files of the library. So I believe I'll delete the noncommutative case.
That shouldn't require that much generalizing, right? To be clear I think that would fit in this PR.
Question: how did you detect that?
Well it looked wrong to my monospace brain, and then I used the fact that GitHub puts a very subtle dot to allow counting spaces. I thought we had a bot for detecting those but apparently not :shrug:

```suggestion
theorem zero : IsTopologicallyNilpotent (0 : R) := 
  tendsto_atTop_of_eventually_const (i₀ := 1)
    (fun _ hi => by rw [zero_pow (Nat.ne_zero_iff_zero_lt.mpr hi)])
```
You can also keep the indentation after the : if you prefer, but having half on the proof in the same line as the statement is a bit weird.

I think you should be able to remove some of the boilerplate by using [Filter.HasBasis.tendsto_iff](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/Bases.html#Filter.HasBasis.tendsto_iff), applied to [IsLinearTopology.hasBasis_twoSidedIdeal](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/LinearTopology.html#IsLinearTopology.hasBasis_twoSidedIdeal) and [Filter.atTop_basis](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/AtTopBot.html#Filter.atTop_basis).
I did not understand what you wanted me to do, I added a lemma and simplified the proof.

I didn't mean splitting the proof (but I'm fine with keeping the intermediate lemma if you think it's useful). I meant: do not start by introducing the neighborhood `v`, instead start by `rw [IsTopologicallyNilpotent, atTop_basis.tendsto_iff IsLinearTopology.hasBasis_twoSidedIdeal]`. This is just using the general criterion of convergence for filters with chosen bases.

I think you should be able to use directly [IsLinearTopology.tendsto_mul_zero_of_left](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/LinearTopology.html#IsLinearTopology.tendsto_mul_zero_of_left) instead of appealing to an ideal basis here. Same for the lemma below.
